item.title: Notes: Educating intuition
item.description: References Citekey: @hogarth2001 Hogarth, R. M. (2001). Educating intuition. Chicago, Ill.: University of Chicago Press. Notes Hogarth defines intuition as responses ‘reached with little apparent effort, and typically without conscious effort. They involve little or no conscious deliberation’ (p. 14). Hogarth pursues the question of whether we can rely upon our intuition. That is, should we let our intuition guide our decision making? The answer that emerges from the book is not a simple ‘yes’ or ‘no’.
